title: 108_hr1287
content: The Act titled "Comprehensive Health Care Reform Act of 2003" provides a refundable credit for health care costs under Section 35 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Comprehensive Health Care Reform Act of 2003" offers a refundable credit for health care costs. An individual can claim a tax credit for medical care insurance paid for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is limited to the taxpayer's net income tax and social security taxes for the taxable year. Any credit received cannot be used to determine deductions. The "Comprehensive Health Care Reform Act of 2003" repeals certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including Section 162(l) and Section 202 of the Trade Act of 2002. It also amends the item relating to section 35 in the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by Section 35 regarding health insurance costs will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. Additionally, Section 3 deals with the disposition of unused health benefits in cafeteria plans and flexible spending arrangements. Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for carryforwards or payments of up to $500 of unused health benefits in cafeteria plans, without causing the plan to lose its status. The amendment to Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for the distribution of unused health benefits on behalf of an employee, which is includible in gross income and wages of the employee. Unused health benefits paid as compensation by the employer are excludable from gross income to a certain extent. The amendment to Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for the distribution of unused health benefits as compensation by the employer, which can be excluded from gross income and wages of the employee. Unused health benefits must be part of a health flexible spending arrangement and only reimburse for medical care expenses. The amendment to Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code, effective after December 31, 2003, allows for reimbursement under a health flexible spending arrangement to be distributed as compensation if it exceeds the actual amount reimbursed during the plan year. SEC. 4. EXPANSION OF AVAILABILITY OF ARCHER MEDICAL SAVINGS ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Dollar Limitations on Archer MSA Contributions and Limitations on Medical Savings Accounts are repealed in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing certain sections related to high deductible health plans and eligible individuals. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to remove sections related to high deductible health plans and eligible individuals. This includes changes to health plans not covered under a high deductible plan and conforming amendments to various sections of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to remove sections related to high deductible health plans and eligible individuals. This includes changes to health plans not covered under a high deductible plan and conforming amendments to various sections of the Code, such as coordination with exclusion for employer contributions and reduction of permitted deductibles under high deductible health plans. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the dollar amounts for high deductible health plans. The amendment reduces the deductible amounts from $1,500 to $1,000 and from $3,000 to $2,000. Additionally, a cost-of-living adjustment provision is added for taxable years after 1998. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for high deductible health plans. The amendment reduces deductibles to $1,000 and $2,000. Special rules apply for calendar years 1992, 1997, and 2002. Incentives for Preferred Provider Organizations to offer Medical Savings Accounts are provided. Medical Savings Accounts may be offered under Cafeteria Plans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code adjusts dollar amounts for high deductible health plans, reducing deductibles to $1,000 and $2,000. Subsection (f) of section 125 is amended by striking "106(b)," and the effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2003. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF 7.5 PERCENT THRESHOLD ON DEDUCTION FOR MEDICAL EXPENSES. Amends section 213 of the Internal Revenue Code to remove the 7.5 percent threshold for deducting medical expenses. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
